intro: Astragalus zadaensis, commonly known as Zada's milkvetch, is a flowering plant belonging to the legume family, Fabaceae. It is native to the arid and semi-arid regions of Central Asia, particularly in Afghanistan and Pakistan. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to drought conditions. It features compound leaves and produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in summer. Astragalus zadaensis is known for its ecological significance in stabilizing soil and supporting local wildlife.
